CHAPTER 1 



PROJECT TITLE:

Intelligent  Fault  Detection and Diagnosis in Electrical Grids





OBJECTIVE:

To  develop  an  intelligent  system using computational intelligence techniques (e.g., machine learning, fuzzy logic) for real-time fault detection and classification in power grids.







Faults in the Electric Grid: A Comprehensive Overview



Electric power systems are critical infrastructures that deliver electricity from generation plants to consumers through a network of transmission and distribution lines. For the system to

function reliably, it must maintain stability, continuity, and quality of supply. However, faults—which are abnormal conditions in the electrical network—can disrupt this stability,

damage equipment, and lead to blackouts. Understanding faults, their types, causes, and

consequences is essential for designing robust and intelligent fault detection and protection mechanisms.



What is a Fault in an Electric Grid?



A fault in an electric grid is defined as any abnormal flow of electric current. This typically involves a short circuit, where the current bypasses the normal load due to an unintended

connection between two or more conductors, or between a conductor and the ground. Faults can cause sudden increases in current (fault current), leading to overheating, equipment damage, and even fire.

They also result in voltage dips and power quality issues.



Faults are undesirable but unavoidable events in a power system. The goal of engineers is not to eliminate faults entirely—which is practically impossible—but to detect, isolate, and mitigate them quickly and efficiently.



Classification of Faults

Faults in an electric grid can be broadly classified into two categories: symmetrical and unsymmetrical faults.



Symmetrical Faults (Balanced Faults)



These faults affect all three phases equally and maintain system symmetry. Though they are rare, symmetrical faults are the most severe, often resulting in significant damage due to high fault currents.

 Three-Phase Fault (3Φ or LLL): All three phase conductors are shorted together, either directly or through a fault impedance. This is the most serious type of fault but occurs infrequently.

Example: Lightning strike causing a metallic short across all three phases on a transmission line.



Unsymmetrical Faults (Unbalanced Faults)



These faults affect only one or two phases, disrupting the balance of the system. They are more common and can be of several types:

Single Line-to-Ground Fault(SLG or LG): One phase comes into contact with the ground or a grounded object.

	Occurrence: Most common (around 70% of all faults).

	Example: A tree branch falls on a power line, connecting it to the ground.

Line-to-Line Fault (LL): Two phases come into contact with each other.

	Occurrence: Less common than SLG, but more damaging than a single-phase fault.

Double Line-to-Ground Fault (LLG): Two phases come into contact with each other and the ground.

	Occurrence: More severe than SLG or LL, but less common than SLG.

Causes of Electrical Faults

Numerous internal and external factors can cause faults in the power system:





Fuzzy Logic Systems are used to deal with uncertainty and imprecision in fault diagnosis.

Wavelet Transforms and Fourier Transforms extract meaningful features from transient signals for better classification.

 Phasor Measurement Units(PMUs) provide real-time data for wide-area fault detection.

             Real-Time Fault Management in Smart Grids



As power systems evolve into smart grids, real-time monitoring and intelligent fault management have become essential. Key technologies include:

Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition(SCADA) systems that continuously monitor voltage, current, and equipment status.

 IoT sensors deployed across transmission and distribution networks. 	

 Edge computing for localized, low-latency fault detection.

Artificial   Intelligence to predict faults before they occur using historical and real-time data.



Importance of Fault Studies in Grid Design

Conducting fault analysis is a critical part of power system planning and design. It helps in:  Determining the rating of circuit breakers and protective devices.

Designing grounding systems to safely dissipate fault currents.  Ensuring system stability under fault conditions.

Implementing selective protection schemes to minimize disruption





Faults in the electric grid are inevitable but must be efficiently managed to ensure reliable and stable power delivery. Understanding the types, causes, and consequences of faults is

the first step toward building effective protection and detection systems. With the increasing complexity of modern power systems, the integration of computational intelligence techniques such as

machine learning and fuzzy logic is transforming fault management, enabling faster response times and higher accuracy. As the world moves toward more

resilient and intelligent grid infrastructure, fault detection and classification will remain a cornerstone of system reliability and safety.



CHAPTER – 2



Using Machine Learning for Fault Detection in Electric Power Systems

Introduction



Electric power systems are critical to modern society, supplying energy to industries, homes, and infrastructure. However, these systems are susceptible to faults, such as short circuits, line-to-ground faults, or equipment failures, which can cause blackouts, equipment damage, and safety hazards.

Traditional methods of fault detection rely heavily on fixed threshold

values and rule-based systems, which may not perform effectively in complex, real-time environments.



In recent years, Machine Learning(ML) has emerged as a powerful tool for intelligent fault detectionand classification in electric power systems. ML algorithms can learn from historical data, recognize patterns, adapt to changing conditions, and make accurate

predictions in real-time. This essay explores how ML is used in fault detection, its benefits and limitations, and the promising future it holds for smart grid systems.





How Machine Learning Is Used for Fault Detection

Data Acquisition and Preprocessing



Machine learning begins with data. For fault detection in power systems, this includes:  

Voltage and current waveforms

 Frequency measurements

 Harmonic distortions  

Phase angles

 Weather data (e.g., lightning, wind)  

Historical fault logs

This data is collected from SCADA systems, Phasor Measurement Units(PMUs), Intelligent Electronic Devices(IEDs), or smart sensors. Preprocessing involves filtering noise, normalizing features, and labeling fault events for supervised learning.



Feature Extraction



Raw data is often transformed into meaningful features using:



	Statistical metrics (mean, RMS, peak value, standard deviation) 

 Time-domain features (zero-crossing, slope)

 Frequency-domain analysis (FFT)

	Time-frequency techniques (Wavelet Transform)

	Principal Component Analysis(PCA) for dimensionality reduction



These features help ML models learn distinguishing characteristics of normal and faulty conditions.



Model Training



Machine learning models are trained to recognize patterns associated with faults. Commonly used algorithms include:

Support Vector Machines (SVM): Effective for binary and multiclass fault classification.  Decision Trees and Random Forests: Handle non-linear data well and are interpretable.  k-Nearest Neighbors (k- NN): Classifies based on similarity to historical cases.

 Neural Networks (including Deep Learning): Powerful for complex, high-dimensional data like waveform patterns.

Logistic Regression: Simple and effective for binary fault detection tasks.

Fault Detection and Classification

Once trained, ML models can:



  Detect faults in real-time based on live data streams.

Classify fault types (e.g., single line-to-ground, line-to-line, three-phase).  Localize faults to specific areas of the network.

Predict potential faults before they occur (predictive maintenance).

Advantages of Using Machine Learning for Fault Detection

Accuracy and Speed

ML models can detect and classify faults with high accuracy, often faster than traditional protection systems. This is particularly valuable in time-critical scenarios.

Adaptability

ML algorithms can be retrained with new data, making them adaptive to changing grid conditions, new fault types, or aging equipment.

Handling Non-Linearity

Many power system behaviors are non-linear. ML models, especially neural networks and tree- based models, excel in capturing these complex relationships.

Data-Driven Insights

ML doesn’t require explicit programming of rules. Instead, it learns patterns directly from data, making it suitable for evolving and uncertain environments.

Real-Time Monitoring



With proper integration, ML models can operate in real-time to assist operators or automated systems in decision-making.



1.Predictive Maintenance



ML can identify patterns that precede faults, enabling proactive maintenance and reducing unplanned outages.

Disadvantages and Challenges

Data Requirements

ML requires large amounts of quality data. In many real-world systems, labeled fault data may be scarce, especially for rare or new fault types.

Model Interpretability

Some ML models (like deep neural networks) act as “black boxes.” In critical applications like power systems, lack of explainability can hinder trust and adoption.

Overfitting

If not carefully managed, ML models may perform well on training data but poorly in real- world scenarios. Regularization, validation, and testing are essential.



2.Computational Complexity

Complex models may require significant computational resources, making real-time implementation difficult on low-power edge devices.

Cybersecurity and Robustness

ML models can be vulnerable to adversarial inputs or data poisoning. Ensuring robustness and security is crucial in mission-critical systems.

Integration with Legacy Systems

Integrating ML solutions into traditional SCADA or grid infrastructure may require significant upgrades or interfaces, adding to implementation cost.

Future Prospects of ML in Fault Detection

The future of ML in fault detection is bright, especially with the rise of smart grids, Internetof Things (IoT), and edge computing. Key future directions include:

Deep Learning and Hybrid Models



Deep learning models like Convolutional Neural Networks(CNNs) and LongShort-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are increasingly used to analyze raw waveform data. Combining these with traditional models (e.g., hybrid CNN-RF) offers robust solutions for real-time

systems.



Edge AI

Deploying ML models on edge devices (e.g., smart sensors, microcontrollers) allows for real- time fault detection without relying on cloud infrastructure. This reduces latency and

enhances system resilience.



Transfer Learning

Using pre-trained models on one system and adapting them to another with minimal

retraining (transfer learning) can reduce data requirements and improve generalization across different grids.



Explainable AI (XAI)

As trust and transparency are critical in power systems, the field of XAI is growing. It aims to make ML decisions interpretable by humans, helping operators understand why a fault was flagged.

Reinforcement Learning

Reinforcement learning can be applied to dynamic control problems, such as reconfiguration after fault isolation or optimal load shedding during fault conditions.

Federated Learning

This approach allows multiple grid operators or devices to train shared ML models collaboratively without exchanging raw data—enhancing privacy and security.



Conclusion

Machine Learning offers transformative potential for fault detection in electric power systems, improving accuracy, speed, adaptability, and predictive capability. While there are

challenges—such as data quality, interpretability, and computational requirements—ongoing research and technological advancements are rapidly addressing these limitations.

As power systems evolve into more intelligent, decentralized,  and data-driven networks, ML will become a cornerstone of fault management and grid reliability. By enabling real-time

decision-making, predictive diagnostics, and adaptive control, machine learning is paving the way for the future of smart, self-healing electric grids.



CHAPTER 3



LOGISTIC REGRESSION



 Logistic Regression is one of the simplest and most widely used machine learning algorithms for binary classification problems, including fault detection in electric grids (e.g., fault vs. no-fault, or specific fault types). Although more advanced methods like neural networks or

ensemble models are also used, logistic regression can still play a valuable role in certain applications.

Why Use Logistic Regression for Fault Detection in Electric Grids?

Logistic Regression is used in fault detection when the goal is to classify whether a fault has occurred or not, based on features such as:

 Voltage dips or spikes Current surges

 Frequency deviations

 Time-domain features (RMS, peak)

	Transformed features (wavelets, FFT)

It can also be extended to multiclass classification (e.g., SLG, LL, LLG faults) using techniques like One-vs-Rest or Softmax regression (a form of multinomial logistic regression).

Advantages of Using Logistic Regression



Advantage

Explanation

1. Simplicity

Easy to understand and implement, especially in academic or initial stages of a project.

2. Fast Training

Trains quickly even on large datasets with many features.

3. Interpretable

Model outputs probabilities and provides insight into the influence of each feature.

4. Low Computational Cost

Suitable for embedded and real-time systems withlimited resources.

5. Performs Well on Linearly Separable Data

Effective when fault and non-fault conditions are linearly separable in feature space.

6. Probabilistic Output

Outputs probabilities (e.g., 65% chance of fault), useful for decision thresholds.

7. Good Baseline Model

Often used as a starting point for benchmarking before trying complex models.



Disadvantage

Assumes Linearity





Not Ideal for Complex Fault Patterns





Sensitive to Outliers



Requires Feature Scaling





May Underperform on Imbalanced Datasets





Limited in Handling Multiclass Cases

Explanation

Assumes a linear relationship between features and log-odds of the outcome, which might not hold in complex electrical systems. May fail to capture nonlinear or intricate

fault characteristics unless features are

carefully engineered.

Outliers can heavily influence the model’s

parameters.

For optimal performance, input features should be scaled (especially when using regularization).

Fault detection datasets are often imbalanced (few faults vs. many normal conditions), and logistic regression can be biased toward the majority class.

Needs adaptation (e.g., One-vs-Rest) for multiclass fault classification.



When Is Logistic Regression a Good Choice?



When the dataset is small to medium-sized.



When the features are well understood and the relationship with the output is somewhat linear.



For quick prototyping or baseline performance before testing more complex models. 



In real-time or embedded systems with constrained computational power.

Understand the Dataset



You should first understand:

 What type of faults (e.g., short-circuit, line-to-ground)? Sensor types (voltage, current, frequency)?

Data format (time series, logs, waveforms)?

 Target variable (regression on fault magnitude or classification of fault type? 2. Data Cleaning

Remove missing values: Use imputation or delete incomplete rows.

 Filter noise: Apply signal processing techniques like low-pass filters or wavelet transforms

if dealing with time-series voltage/current data.

  Remove duplicates: Especially important in log or event-based data.

Feature Engineering

You can extract useful features like:

 RMS value of voltage or current  Frequency deviations

  Rate of change (dV/dt or dI/dt)

 Harmonic components using FFT  Time sincelastfault

 Duration of fault

 Phase imbalances

Linear regression requires numerical and continuous features — if you have categorical data (like "fault type"), use one-hot encoding.

Linear regression assumes features are on comparable scales.



2.Use Standard Scaler (Z-score normalization) or Min-Max Scaler python CopyEdit from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler



scaler = StandardScaler() X_scaled = scaler.flt_transform(X)

Outlier Detection and Handling

Electrical faults can create extreme values.

Use IQR, Z-score, or Isolation Forest to detect and remove or flagoutliers.

If the outliers represent actual faults, keep them; if they are noise, remove.

Time-Series Considerations (if applicable)

If data is time-series:

Use lag features, rolling statistics (mean, std).

Make sure to avoid data leakage (don’t use future data to predictthepast). Use train-test split chronologically.

Dimensionality Reduction (Optional)

If you have too many features (from sensors), use:  PCA (Principal Component Analysis)

LDA (if supervised)

Label Preparation

If you're using linear regression:

Your target variable (y) must be continuous (e.g., fault severity, voltage drop, time to repair).



 If you're detecting fault types, consider classification models instead (like logistic regression, SVM, etc.).

Final Preprocessing Checklist



Step

Purpose

Data Cleaning

Remove noises fill missing values

Feature Engineering

Extract meaningful signals

Feature Scaling

Normalize for model performance

Outlier Handling

Avoid skewed predictions

Train-Test Split

CHAPTER -5



Dataset and Variables

The dataset used in this project is the “Fault Simulation Dataset for 110 kV Power Transmission Lines”

generated for a real-size 110 kV network.

For every simulation case, the input variables – electrical features are











So each row of the dataset represents one system condition, described by 24 voltage/current magnitudes.

These values are per-unit / scaled simulation outputs, not raw 110 kV / kA numbers. In power- system studies this is standard: the absolute magnitude is less important than how the voltages and currents change under different faults.



Output Variable





Fault

spgf – single-phase-to-ground fault

2psc – two-phase short circuit

3psc – three-phase short circuit

No- fault – normal operating condition

We applied Label Encoder, so in the code the four classes appear numerically as 0, 1, 2, 3, but they correspond directly to these physical fault types.



CHAPTER – 6

ML Pipeline Flow Diagram

















The complete ML pipeline for the proposed fault-type classifier consists of five stages: raw data acquisition, cleaning and label encoding, feature scaling using Z-score normalization, stratified train/test data splitting, and finally training a multiclass logistic regression model. This pipeline is shown schematically

The flow chart summarises your entire machine-learning pipeline:





Raw Data

The original CSV from the 110 kV fault simulation dataset (24 inputs + fault/line/position targets).



Drop NA / Encode



Drop NA:

Remove any rows with missing values (NaN) to avoid feeding incomplete electrical measurements to the model.

Encode:

Apply Label Encoder to transform the categorical fault label (spgf, 2psc, 3psc, no- fault) into numeric codes 0–3, which the model can handle.



Scaling



Perform Z-score normalization (standardization) on all 24 input features:



so every feature has mean 0 and standard deviation 1.

It ensures that large-magnitude features (currents) do not dominate smaller ones (voltages in per-unit), and helps logistic regression converge faster and more stably.



Train/Test Split



The cleaned and scaled dataset is split into:

Training set (80%) – used to fit the logistic regression parameters.

Test set (20%) – held out to evaluate generalization.

The split is typically stratified by class, so each fault type appears in similar proportions in train and test, as the paper also recommends.



Logistic Regression

Final stage: train a multiclass logistic regression model on the training data



CHAPTER – 7

Distribution of Fault Classes (Bar chart “Distribution of Fault Classes”)













That bar plot shows how many samples belong to each of the four classes (0, 1, 2, 3).



The x-axis: Fault Class (0–3) – encoded versions of the four states (three faults + no- fault).

The y-axis: Count – number of rows in the dataset for each class.



From the plot:



Class 2 has the largest count (≈300 samples).

Classes 0, 1, 3 are around ≈100 samples each.



The dataset is moderately imbalanced, with class 2 (one of the fault/no-fault states) having roughly three times more samples than the other classes. However, all four classes are well represented (≈100+ samples each), which is sufficient for training a multiclass logistic regression classifier without severe bias.



CHAPTER – 8

Correlation Matrix (Blue-red heatmap)















The big coloured heatmap is the correlation matrix of the input features.



Each row and column is one feature (Ua1, Ub1, …, Ic5).

Each cell shows the Pearson correlation coefficient between two features:

Values close to +1 (red) → very strong positive correlation.

Values close to −1 (dark blue) → strong negative correlation.

Values near 0 → weak or no linear relationship.



Observations:



Phase voltages at the same bus (Ua1, Ub1, Uc1) are highly correlated, as are currents in the same line (Ia1, Ib1, Ic1, etc.).

Some blocks show correlation ≥ 0.9, indicating multicollinearity between certain measurements (e.g., the three phase currents in the same line behave similarly during faults).

This confirms that the dataset is physically consistent: phases of the same bus/line follow similar patterns during faults.



Connection to the logistic regression model:



Logistic regression assumes a linear decision boundary in feature space and can be sensitive to features with very different scales, but it does not strictly require that features be uncorrelated.

In the project, we have:

keep the original 24 features,

apply standardization (Z-score scaling),

and use logistic regression to directly learn the fault-type decision boundaries.



Hence, Correlation analysis confirms strong physical relationships between many voltage and current features. For neural networks, the original paper applies PCA to reduce multicollinearity. In the proposed logistic-regression-based method we rely on standardized features without PCA, since the classifier still achieves perfect separation among classes (see confusion matrix).

CHAPTER – 11

FUTURE SCOPE



The future scope of a project on fault detection in electrical grids using AI (with linear regression or other ML methods) is broad and impactful, especially in the context of smart grids, renewable energy integration, and power system automation.

Here’s a breakdown of the future potential:

Future Scope of AI-based Fault Detection in Electrical Grids

Smart Grid Integration

  AI-driven fault detection will be a key component of smart grids.

  Enables real-time monitoring, faster fault localization, and automatic rerouting of power.

 Supports self-healing grids —system that detect, isolate, and resolve faults without human intervention.

Integration with IoT and Edge Devices

 Combined with IoT sensors, AI models can be deployed on edge devices to detect faults locally in real-time.

Reduces latency and allows faster response.

Predictive Maintenance

 Instead of reacting to faults, AI can be used to predict equipment failures before they happen.

 Extends the life of transformers, lines, and substations.  Reduces unplanned outages and maintenance costs.

Adaptability to Renewable Energy Systems

 Grids with solar and wind are more variable and fault-prone.  AI can learn to detect faults specific to renewable systems, like inverter failures, islanding, or frequency instability.



Scalable and Transferable Models



 Once developed, the AI model can be scaled across different regions, utilities, and network topologies with minimal tuning.

  Helps in standardizing grid fault diagnostics across countries or states.

Cyber-Physical Security

 AI can be trained to detect anomalies due to cyber-attacks (e.g., data spoofing or coordinated switching).

 Fault detection systems can double as grid intrusion detection systems.

Hybrid Modeling with Deep Learning

 In the future, linear regression models can evolve into hybrid AI systems, combining:

  Deep learning (LSTMs, CNNs) for time-series and spatial fault data

 Physics-informed AI models that integrate domain knowledge of electrical systems

Government and Industry Adoption

 Power utilities and governments worldwide are investing in AI-driven grid modernization.

 Your project can align with national smart grid missions, rural electrification goals, and disaster resilience planning.



In Summary

Our project has scope to:

     Improve grid reliability and efficiency 

      Enable green energy adoption

 Lead to innovative products in grid diagnostics

    Serve as a foundation for startups or research in energy AI



The electrical power system is composed of three key subsystems: generation, transmission, and

distribution. Power is transferred from generation to distribution through the transmission

subsystem, specifically the power transmission lines. A power transmission line is a system of high voltage electrical conductors used to transport electricity over long distances from power generation

plants to substations, where it is then distributed to consumers. However, due to their exposure to

environmental conditions, transmission lines are prone to experiencing different types of faults .

The reliable and stable operation of the power system is crucial to minimizing its impact on

industries, businesses, transportation, and households.

Faults in the power system can lead to

substantial disruptions, resulting in significant financial losses. Therefore, ensuring continuous and

secure power transmission is essential to maintaining a nation's economic activities.

To safeguard the power system network, a failure must be detected, accurately located, and

categorized as soon as it occurs. This prompt action minimizes network outages by allowing for the



swift disconnection of the affected phase . In real-life scenarios, a relay and circuit breaker

perform this operation. The most common methods used in the majority of the field relays

based on phasor estimation. These techniques require capturing one full cycle of post-fault data (20ms for 50 Hz) to produce reliable estimates. This time requirement introduces significant delays in initiating protective actions. Therefore, it is necessary to develop faster algorithms.

The detection, classification, and localization of faults in the power system can be significantly

enhanced through the use of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques. The primary motivation behind this article is to apply deep learning methods to develop efficient,

accurate and reliable fault diagnosis methods for power transmission systems.

The dataset was split into 80% training and 20% testing sets to ensure sufficient data for both model training and evaluation. The split was stratified by fault types to maintain the proportional distribution of each fault class (SPGF, 2PSC, 3PSC, and no-fault) in both the training and testing sets.

Data scaling

Data scaling is a process used to normalize the range of feature values in a dataset, ensuring that all features are on the same scale. In power systems, features such as voltage and current can have different magnitudes and units, and without scaling, features with larger values may dominate the learning process, potentially leading to biased model performance







CHAPTER - 12





	                                                                    DISCUSSION

In this project, an intelligent system was developed for fault detection in high-voltage electrical transmission lines using AI techniques, specifically linear regression. The aim was to create a data-driven model capable of identifying and analyzing different types of faults in a 110 kV power line under varying load conditions.

To simulate realistic fault scenarios, three types of faults were introduced into the system:

Single-Phase-to-Ground Fault (SPGF)

Two-Phase Short Circuit (2PSC)

Three-Phase Short Circuit (3PSC)

Each fault type was applied along the length of a 110 kV transmission line. The fault location was systematically varied from the beginning to the end of the line in 5% increments, allowing the model to learn how fault characteristics change with location.

In addition, to make the model adaptive to dynamic grid behavior, the system load was varied incrementally by 0.1 MW. This variation enabled the simulation of different operating conditions under which faults may occur, enhancing the robustness of the model.

A load flow analysis was performed for each scenario to compute the electrical parameters (such as voltage, current, and power flow) during both normal and fault conditions. These parameters served as input features to train the AI model.

The data generated from these simulations was then used to train a linear regression model to predict fault indicators based on measurable electrical parameters. The model was evaluated for its ability to detect faults and estimate fault characteristics with high accuracy.

Objective:

To develop a lightweight, efficient fault detection model using AI.

To analyze how fault behavior changes with respect to location and load conditions.

  To explore the feasibility of using linear regression for fault identification in power systems.

Significance:

This project provides a foundation for real-time fault detection in smart grid environments. It enables proactive fault management and lays the groundwork for future integration with PMU (Phasor Measurement Unit) data for more accurate and time-synchronized fault localization and prediction.





CHAPTER - 13



AI-Based Fault Detection in Electrical Grids Using Load Flow Analysis and Linear

Regression

Project Description



In this project, an AI-based approach was developed for detecting and analyzing faults in a 110 kV transmission line using linear regression. The objective was to investigate how fault characteristics vary across line locations and different load conditions and to build a predictive model that can detect such faults using measurable electrical parameters.

Three types of faults were considered:

Single-Phase-to-Ground Fault (SPGF) 

Two- Phase Short Circuit(2PSC)

Three-Phase Short Circuit (3PSC)

Each fault type was simulated at varying locations along the transmission line (from 0% to 100% of the line length in 5% increments). Simultaneously, the system load was

incrementally increased by 0.1 MW to simulate different operating conditions. Load flow

analysis was performed to compute essential parameters like voltage, current, and power, which were then used as inputs for model training.



METHODOLOGY

Fault Simulation

 A 110 kV power system model was developed in simulation software (e.g., MATLAB/Simulink, PSCAD, or PowerWorld).

 Faults were injected at multiple locations along the line for each of the three types (SPGF, 2PSC, 3PSC).

 System loads were varied incrementally to study fault behavior under different load levels.

Data Collection via Load Flow Analysis

 For each fault scenario, a load flow analysis was run to gather:  Bus voltages

 Line currents

 Real and reactive power flows  Phase angles

	These electrical quantities were logged as features.

Feature Preparation

 Input features included voltage, current, and power values under various fault and loading conditions.

	The output (target variable) was the fault type or fault presence.

Model Training with Linear Regression

	Linear regression was applied to:

 Detect the presence of faults based on system variables  Estimate fault severity or location

 The dataset was split into training and testing subsets for evaluation.



CHAPTER – 14

RESULTS

 The linear regression model successfully identified fault conditions with good accuracy for most scenarios.

 Fault behavior showed consistent patterns relative to:

		Location: Faults closer to the source had more significant voltage drops.

		Load: Higher loads increased current deviations and power losses, aiding in fault detection.

 And here we are also increasing the load with .1MWto get it fit into real world .

 And a 5% increment length of the locations on transmission line .

 The model was lightweight and fast, suitable for real-time application in future edge devices or PMU-integrated systems.

 Performance metrics (example, can be modified based on actual data):

 Accuracy: 86%

 Mean Squared Error (MSE): Low, indicating minimal prediction error

CONCLUSION:

This project explored the feasibility of applying Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques, specifically logistic regression, for the detection and analysis of electrical faults in a 110 kV power transmission line operating under varying load conditions. The methodology involved simulating multiple fault scenarios, including:

Single Phase-to-Ground Fault (SPGF) 

Two Phase Short Circuit(2PSC)

Three Phase Short Circuit (3PSC)

No Fault Conditions (Normal Operation)

The machine learning pipeline was built to train and validate a logistic regression classifier, selected for its simplicity, interpretability, and efficiency. Despite its simplicity, the model



exhibited high accuracy in classifying fault conditions based on electrical parameters such as current, voltage, and power. This demonstrates that with well-preprocessed and structured data, even basic machine learning algorithms can learn and generalize complex fault behavior effectively.

Key Outcomes:

 Effective Fault Pattern Recognition: Logistic regression achieved robust fault classification performance.  Model Interpretability: The simplicity of the model makes it easier to explain and trust in critical systems.

 Foundational Work for Real-Time Systems: The outcomes provide a stepping stone towards deploying real-time AI-based grid monitoring systems.

Future Scope and Applications:

This research lays the groundwork for more advanced developments, such as:

 Real-time fault detection and alert systems integrated into Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) or Phasor Measurement Unit (PMU)-based monitoring

infrastructures.

 Predictive maintenance frameworks, enabling utilities to anticipate and prevent grid failures before they escalate.  Incorporation of real-world PMU data to validate and generalize the model in real grid environments.

 The results confirm that even simple machine learning models like logistic regression can effectively capture fault patterns when provided with well- prepared electrical data. This work lays the foundation for:

 Real-time AI-based grid fault monitoring systems  Integration with PMU data for improved accuracy 	Predictive maintenance and faster grid restoration

In future work, this approach can be extended using deep learning, real PMU measurements, and classification techniques for fault type identification and location estimation.
